results.abstract: Pres Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton ring in New Year at Renaissance Weekend in Hilton Head, NC (M)

headline.main: Clinton's Unusual Year Ends in the Usual Way

results.snippet: President Clinton rang out his most unusual of years in his usual, if peculiar, way: in very earnest policy discussions with more than a thousand acquaintances and hangers-on -- and a few old friends and unimpressed strangers -- assembled at the...
results.lead_paragraph: President Clinton rang out his most unusual of years in his usual, if peculiar, way: in very earnest policy discussions with more than a thousand acquaintances and hangers-on -- and a few old friends and unimpressed strangers -- assembled at the annual Renaissance Weekend here. For more than an hour as midnight approached on Thursday, the President and Hillary Rodham Clinton fielded questions selected by the event's organizers. In all the talk about Africa, Social Security and health care, impeachment and Monica S. Lewinsky went unmentioned. At midnight the President kissed his wife, then joined in a toast and sang along to ''Auld Lang Syne.''

results.abstract: Thomas Mallon profile of astronaut Alan Shepard, one of notables who died in 1998; photo (S)

headline.main: THE LIVES THEY LIVED: Alan Shepard; 15 Minutes of Fame

results.snippet: In 1961, when Alan Shepard came home with the news that he had been picked to make the first Project Mercury flight, he said to his wife, Louise: ''Lady, you can't tell anyone, but you have your arms around the man who'll be first in space!''    ...
results.lead_paragraph: In 1961, when Alan Shepard came home with the news that he had been picked to make the first Project Mercury flight, he said to his wife, Louise: ''Lady, you can't tell anyone, but you have your arms around the man who'll be first in space!'' ''Who let a Russian in here?'' she replied. It was a better joke than she knew. As things turned out, NASA insisted on two more tests of the Redstone rocket -- one unmanned and one with Ham the chimpanzee -- and by the time Shepard was ready to go, on May 5, Yuri Gagarin had already been there and back. ''We had 'em,'' Shepard said. ''We had 'em by the short hairs, and we gave it away.''

results.abstract: Craig R Whitney travel article on Toulouse, ancient city in southwestern France that is also aerospace capital of Europe; first regularly scheduled airline flights in France took off from Toulouse in 1920's, Airbus consortium now assembles planes in suburb of Colomiers suburb, National Center for Space Research has been in city for thirty years, and air and space museum, La Cite de l'Epace, has been open since 1997; interactive exhibits and other attractions at Space City described; photos; map (M)

headline.main: In Toulouse, a Blast From Past and Present

results.snippet: TOULOUSE, the city of ancient pink-brick churches and stately homes on the Garonne River in southwestern France, may be noted for foie gras, but it is just as proud to be the aerospace capital of Europe.     The first regularly scheduled airline...
results.lead_paragraph: TOULOUSE, the city of ancient pink-brick churches and stately homes on the Garonne River in southwestern France, may be noted for foie gras, but it is just as proud to be the aerospace capital of Europe. The first regularly scheduled airline flights in France took off from the Toulouse airport in the 1920's, and now long-range passenger planes of the Airbus consortium, Boeing's most important rivals in world markets, are assembled in a vast hangar in the suburb of Colomiers; the National Center for Space Research has been centered in Toulouse for 30 years.

results.abstract: In this lesson, students examine the Q.& A. articles found each week in Science Times, focusing on how the answers are presented in a clear and logical way, as well as the relevance of understanding science's roles in our daily lives. Students then write their own questions and answer other classmates' questions in the format of the Science Times Q.&. A. articles.
results.snippet: In this lesson, students examine the Q.& A. articles found each week in Science Times, focusing on how the answers are presented in a clear and logical way, as well as the relevance of understanding science's roles in our daily lives. Students then...
results.lead_paragraph: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

results.abstract: Dr Mario Dario Grossi, radio physicist and engineer who developed concept of tethered satellites as well as hardware that made such free-flying space maneuvers possible, dies at age 74 (M)

headline.main: M. Grossi, 74; Created Tether For Satellites

results.snippet: Dr. Mario Dario Grossi, a radio physicist and engineer who developed the concept of tethered satellites as well as the hardware that made such free-flying space maneuvers possible, died Jan. 11 at Boston Medical Center in Boston. He was 74 and lived...
results.lead_paragraph: Dr. Mario Dario Grossi, a radio physicist and engineer who developed the concept of tethered satellites as well as the hardware that made such free-flying space maneuvers possible, died Jan. 11 at Boston Medical Center in Boston. He was 74 and lived in Cambridge, Mass. The cause was congestive heart failure, his family said.

results.abstract: Anita Gates Critic's Notebook on advertisers' efforts to woo young male television viewers; brief description of some of programs on Nielsen Media Research's list of 25 most popular shows among 18-to-34-year-old males; photo (M)
results.snippet: I am beginning to feel sorry for males ages 18 to 34. They have nothing to watch on television. Yes, they watch ''E.R.'' and ''Friends,'' as the women in their lives do, but when they're left alone in a room with a remote, channels change.    ...
results.lead_paragraph: I am beginning to feel sorry for males ages 18 to 34. They have nothing to watch on television. Yes, they watch ''E.R.'' and ''Friends,'' as the women in their lives do, but when they're left alone in a room with a remote, channels change. Apparently, in their desperate search for macho stimulation, young men are reduced to tuning in to wrestling shows in which the fighters hit their opponents with metal folding chairs (this sort of thing is done much more convincingly on ''The Jerry Springer Show'') and lowbrow documentary programming like ''World's Wildest Police Videos'' on Fox. During a recent episode, there was, judging by the number of sirens, more action going on outside my living room window (on West End Avenue) than on the screen.
